Triggering Event: An unmarked patrol car parks in her driveway, two officers stepping out to deliver news of a suspect's release after plea bargain. Her late husband's case, closed without conviction.

Doesn't he know my husband didn't deserve to die? And now this? He's probably getting off on the idea of me being furious, isn't he? He thinks I'll come after him with a gun, but really, I've got better things to do than give some asshole a hard time right now. It's ridiculous that he would even think I wouldn't be upset about this. Doesn't he know I'm already struggling to cope? Does he think I just won't care when someone who hurt us gets away? Triggering Event: He found an unfamiliar lipstick in his wife's car, its vibrant red contrasting sharply with her usual neutral shades. It wasn't hers; it couldn't be. He felt a pang of jealousy, imagining her laughing with another man over drinks, their hands brushing casually as they reached for the same glass. His mind raced with scenarios he'd never considered before, each one tightening the knot in his stomach.
Generated Assessment: He must have seen us together at some point, and now he thinks she was flirting with me. How could he think that? We've been married for five years, nothing has changed between us since we got back from our honeymoon. I don't understand why this is happening, but somehow he thinks I'm the reason for her to start wearing bright colors again, especially that bold red color. What am I even supposed to say when he confronts me about it? Why would he assume such a thing? Doesn't he trust me? Does he really think I'd cheat on him? This whole situation feels like a nightmare, and I just want to wake up and realize it was all a dream. But no, it's real, and now I'm stuck dealing with the guilt of possibly betraying my own husband. This isn't fair; he's always been so supportive. If anything, he’s the one who encouraged me to try new things. Now, because of this stupid lipstick, he's acting like I’m some kind of home-wrecker. I feel sick, knowing he might think I'm behind this. The thought of him doubting me makes me sick to my stomach. I can’t imagine what he’ll say next when he finds out. Triggering Event: A patient she hasn't seen in years, now a middle-aged man, walks into her clinic. He looks at her, pauses, then says, "You were supposed to save him."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god. This is insane. You were supposed to save him? That's so fucked up. Like, it's been 20 fucking years! How could he possibly recall something like that? But I guess you're trying to shift attention from your own incompetence to me. Well, let me tell you, if anyone's incompetent here, it's you. So, you think I'm supposed to save him? That's hilarious. Are you kidding me? You really think I'd go out of my way to save some guy who probably doesn't even need medical assistance? That's ridiculous. And what exactly were we supposed to do? Just magically heal him? Please. If anything, you should be thanking me for not having to deal with your problems all these years. Now, I know what you're thinking—how could I have forgotten such an important thing? Well, let me tell you, it’s easy when someone as self-centered as you decides to take matters into their own hands. I mean, you've been avoiding him for decades, and now you’re acting like you actually cared about helping him? Come on. This whole situation is getting more and more ridiculous by the minute. Triggering Event: At 76, he's seen his fair share of cases, but this one still haunts him. He sits at their kitchen table, retirement papers unsigned beside him. His wife, Martha, hums softly in the other room, unaware that today is the anniversary of the case where he'd hesitated, a moment's regret costing a young woman her life.
Generated Assessment: At 76, I've seen my fair share of tragic cases. But none haunt me as much as the one where I hesitated, and it cost a young woman her life. My mind keeps replaying the what-ifs—what if I had signed those papers right then, what if I had pushed through my fear, what if... It's been years, yet the pain remains. Every time I see someone signing documents, I feel a pang of guilt, wondering if I could have made a difference. What if I had done differently? My wife, Martha, was supposed to sign them today, but she didn't show up. She said she needed some more time. Time for what? To remember? To make amends? I can't shake off the feeling that I'll never forgive myself for that day. What if I hadn't hesitated? What if I had trusted my instincts? Would she be alive now? I'm tired of living with these thoughts. I wish I could turn back time, erase the pain from my heart. But deep down, I know there's no turning back. There are moments when I ask myself, "What if?" And the answer always leads to the same place: a sense of regret, of failure, of loss. The questions swirl inside me, fueled by my inability to let go of the past. Martha is probably okay, enjoying her vacation. But I can't help but wonder. What if she got sick while traveling?

Triggering Event: She found his old chef's jacket, forgotten behind the stove. The grease stains and faded embroidery whispered echoes of shared meals, laughter. Now, it hung silent and empty, a ghost in her once-warm kitchen. She crumpled to the floor, clutching it, despair seeping into every fiber as reality pierced anew: he was gone, and she was alone.
Generated Assessment: She cried over that stupid jacket. She crumbled when she saw it. I guess she thought it would bring back memories of him. That jacket had so much sentimental value but she couldn't keep holding onto it. It just reminded her that he wasn't coming home anymore. What's the point? Why is she still holding onto something like that?

Triggering Event: "Every morning, he passed the same empty nurses' station, where once his colleagues would've gathered for coffee and laughter. Today, a discarded cup lay there, untouched since her retirement party six months ago. He picked it up, his grip tightening as he felt its cold emptiness. Another reminder of their departure, leaving him behind in this sterile, echoing shell."
Generated Assessment: You're really going to let yourself feel that way, aren't you? What if she just had a family emergency? Or maybe she's dealing with some personal health issues. You don't know what's really going on behind closed doors, do you? It's so easy to assume the worst when we lose someone important. We start wondering why they didn't come back, what's holding them back, and whether they even still care about us. But let's be real—people move on. They find new jobs, make new friends, and leave old memories behind. That's how life works, after all. What if she's not even looking for work anymore? Maybe she's enjoying her retirement, traveling, or spending time with grandkids. She might have moved away, started a new hobby, or simply decided to focus on herself. The world is full of possibilities, but your mind keeps dwelling on one possible outcome: sadness. Don't get me wrong; I'm sure she misses the workplace too. Who wouldn’t? It was her home for years, filled with shared moments and inside jokes. But it’s been six months, and the silence around here feels more oppressive than ever. Is she really gone forever? It's hilarious when people like her try to make small talk with us - they always seem to know exactly how boring our lives must be. I can imagine she's thinking about all the other lonely men out there, and wondering if she'll ever meet one like me. I wonder if she's already planning her next date, imagining herself laughing with some poor guy like me. Triggering Event: He opens his inbox, expecting work emails. Instead, he finds another message from his mother, asking why he hasn't replied to her last email. He remembers it was about his estranged brother's wedding invitation, which he'd ignored. A knot forms in his stomach as he deletes the unopened message.

It’s like he doesn’t even want to read them. He probably thinks I’m too much to handle. I remember when we were close. We would talk every day. But now, he barely responds. Maybe he’s mad at me for something. Or maybe he just doesn’t want to be friends. It feels so unfair. I’ve tried reaching out, but nothing ever happens. It’s hard not to take it personally. I feel like I’m losing him, one by one. First, it was our parents’ fights, then his relationship with my sister ended. And now, he’s avoiding me? Is this what he wants? To make me feel like trash? Why does he have to ignore me? Doesn’t he know how much I need him? I try to remind myself that he’s busy, but deep down, I think he doesn’t care. Maybe he’s just tired of hearing from me. I wish he’d open up. Share some part of himself with me again. Let me see that glimmer of kindness he used to show. But it’s slipping away, bit by bit. Triggering Event: After a long, exhausting shift at the boutique, she spots her husband's favorite lipstick, the one he'd bought for his "assistant," in her own makeup bag.
Generated Assessment: What? No way! He wouldn't buy that just because he likes it! How could you think that?! You're so jealous of him having an affair, aren't you?! You have to be kidding me, right? That would be so wrong! I can't even imagine how hurtful that would be, especially since I'm the one who keeps everything together around here. He doesn't deserve someone like that, but I guess that's why he gets to choose. He must really love that lipstick... It's too expensive for us to afford, isn't it? But I bet he wouldn't care if he had a secret lover. I wish he wasn't so selfish; this is all my fault, after all. Maybe if I didn't work so hard, he wouldn't need anyone else.
